title: Unsupervised EEG-based decoding of absolute auditory attention with canonical correlation analysis
author: Nicolas Heintz (KU Leuven), Tom Francart (KU Leuven), Alexander Bertrand (KU Leuven), ...
relevance_why: The paper introduces unsupervised methods for EEG-based auditory attention decoding, directly aligning with techniques applicable in speech and audio processing, which is relevant for Haohe Liu’s work on audio and speech.
background: Decoding whether a subject is actively listening to an auditory stimulus using EEG signals, contrasting with traditional methods that rely on supervised learning and explicit labeling.
contribution: This paper introduces an unsupervised auditory attention decoding algorithm that employs canonical correlation analysis to improve EEG-based predictions, achieving higher accuracy and adaptability than existing supervised models.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods required labeled data for training, which limited applicability in real-world scenarios where attention labels are not available.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work implements a self-adaptive CCA model that can utilize unlabeled data, allowing it to adjust to non-stationary EEG signals without the need for a calibration phase.

key_innovation: Leveraging a combination of canonical correlation analysis and minimally informed linear discriminant analysis to achieve an unsupervised decoding model that adapts to individual EEG patterns.
real_world_impact: This work paves the way for implementing real-time auditory attention monitoring in wearable devices, enhancing applications in hearing aids and neurofeedback.
limitations: No specific limitations were mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.canonical correlation analysis: **Canonical correlation analysis (CCA)** is a statistical method used to identify relationships between two multivariate datasets by finding linear combinations of variables from both datasets that are maximally correlated.
new_terms.minimally informed linear discriminant a: **Minimally informed linear discriminant analysis (MILDA)** is a classifier variant designed to minimize reliance on labeled data while still providing effective separability between classes.
